text:
Overthinking capital letters call for help :joy:  Currently building out our product copy guidelines and could use a fresh perspective. We have a product called Tours at <http://www.trychameleon.com|Chameleon>, which lets you build a product tour to show users in your platform. How does this set of rules sound to you:

_To create effective *Tours,* follow our design guide._
_Your *Tour* is live!_  (this is where I'm doubting myself as it's possessive :thinking_face:  does the capitalization sound right?)
_25% of PLG companies are using *tours* in their product to boost engagement_ (general - so no capitalization)

elements.text: Overthinking capital letters call for help

, which lets you build a product tour to show users in your platform. How does this set of rules sound to you:
To create effective
Tours,
follow our design guide.
Your
Tour
is live!
(this is where I'm doubting myself as it's possessive
does the capitalization sound right?)
25% of PLG companies are using
tours
in their product to boost engagement
(general - so no capitalization)

text: CAPS if your product name has CAPS in it. Why would you change it?

elements.text: CAPS if your product name has CAPS in it. Why would you change it?

text: This structure makes sense to me---not dissimilar from how seasons and the word "earth" are handled.

elements.text: This structure makes sense to me---not dissimilar from how seasons and the word "earth" are handled.

text: Thanks for the feedback <@UJJFDTN8G> and <@UJDPMTREY>! Good to know I'm on the right track. It's difficult when Tour, the product, can be so many other lower-case _tours_ – a case of looking at something for too long too :sweat_smile:

elements.text: Thanks for the feedback
and
! Good to know I'm on the right track. It's difficult when Tour, the product, can be so many other lower-case
tours
– a case of looking at something for too long too

text:
In regular UX copy terms, it would be "tours" <@U0192SVNRD4>, but since this is the product name, capitalizing works!

One thing to note in your guidelines is to make it clear when to capitalize and when not to capitalize. I'm sure you don't want only capitalized Tours all the time :grin:

elements.text: In regular UX copy terms, it would be "tours"

, but since this is the product name, capitalizing works!

One thing to note in your guidelines is to make it clear when to capitalize and when not to capitalize. I'm sure you don't want only capitalized Tours all the time

text:
i have nothing helpful to add, just wanted to say I really empathise with the whole _"I've stared at this sentence so long that I'm starting to doubt which language it's in"_ problem :upside_down_face:

the shorter the copy, the harder it is to write and the easier it is to overthink

text: Ahh I feel this (overthinking capital letters). But in my case it’s usually because someone else (not a member of the marketing team) has sent over copy and capitalized too many words. :woman-facepalming::skin-tone-2: Then I start to question my instincts re:capitalization. :joy:

elements.text: Ahh I feel this (overthinking capital letters). But in my case it’s usually because someone else (not a member of the marketing team) has sent over copy and capitalized too many words.

text:
Content folks!,

I am both looking for inspiration and wanting to learn from other people’s success, so here is a question for all of you…

*What’s the most successful* piece of content* you’ve ever worked on?*

_*where ‘success’ means “it accomplished what I wanted it to accomplish”, whichever metric that was, and ‘content’ means whatever you want it to mean_ :wink:

elements.text:

text:
I have been doing a 30-min meeting and asking generally for "needs" from my team. I think your note about phrasing like this will really help:

2-3 bullet points of what they are focusing on or working on now that content creators should know about. (Opportunities to collab or focus, etc)

 (and emailing them before with the homework to send that over!)

text: I created an Excel spreadsheet that event creators could plot their marketing and advertising activities on a Gantt chart. It took a couple of hours to create, generated hundreds or thousands of leads, and contributed millions of dollars in revenue over four years.

elements.text: I created an Excel spreadsheet that event creators could plot their marketing and advertising activities on a Gantt chart. It took a couple of hours to create, generated hundreds or thousands of leads, and contributed millions of dollars in revenue over four years.

text: <@UUH2EB134> that must be one of the greatest content ROI stories of all time!

elements.text: that must be one of the greatest content ROI stories of all time!

text:
<@U017WRJTKF1> we excepted it to be successful. But we couldn’t imagine it’d be as successful as it did. We later repurposed it for event creators who ran multiple events at once by changing the title and adding “duplicate the tab for each event” in the instructions. That version was just as successful and didn’t cannibalize the original. 

There are a lot things I’m proud of from my time at Eventbrite. But this example demonstrates the potential of content marketing the best.

elements.text: we excepted it to be successful. But we couldn’t imagine it’d be as successful as it did. We later repurposed it for event creators who ran multiple events at once by changing the title and adding “duplicate the tab for each event” in the instructions. That version was just as successful and didn’t cannibalize the original.
There are a lot things I’m proud of from my time at Eventbrite. But this example demonstrates the potential of content marketing the best.

text: <https://www.eventbrite.com/blog/academy/template-plan-your-events-marketing-and-advertising-activities/|https://www.eventbrite.com/blog/academy/template-plan-your-events-marketing-and-advertising-activities/>

attachments.title: Event Marketing Templates For Planning Your Advertising Activities
attachments.text: Promoting your event is hard work. There are email invites to send, early bird discounts to offer, and paid online and social media advertising campaigns to deploy. On top of all of that, you must juggle the day-to-day logistics to make your event a success. That’s why you need a gameplan.Download this handy template, which will help you plot your marketing and advertising activities into a sample 16-week promotional calendar that you can adapt to your specific needs.Fill out the form to download the sample and start putting your plan into action.
attachments.fallback: Eventbrite US Blog: Event Marketing Templates For Planning Your Advertising Activities

elements.text: https://www.eventbrite.com/blog/academy/template-plan-your-events-marketing-and-advertising-activities/
